terms.definition: A professional responsible for ensuring that manufacturing processes, systems, and equipment meet regulatory requirements and operate consistently within specified parameters in industries like biotech.
Food and Drug Administration - the U.S. federal agency responsible for regulating and supervising the safety of drugs, biological products, and medical devices.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and maintain accurate records of modifications.
Good Manufacturing Practices - a set of regulations and guidelines that ensure products are consistently produced and controlled according to quality standards.
Installation Qualification - a validation protocol that verifies equipment is installed correctly and meets design specifications before operational use.
Operational Qualification - a validation study that confirms equipment operates within specified parameters and functions as intended.
Performance Qualification - a validation protocol that demonstrates a system consistently performs according to specifications under normal operating conditions.
European Medicines Agency - the European Union's regulatory body responsible for the evaluation and supervision of medicinal products.
Corrective and Preventive Actions - systematic processes used to investigate, address, and prevent the recurrence of quality issues or deviations.
A security method that restricts system access and document permissions based on a user's role within an organization, ensuring appropriate levels of access control.
A collaborative feature that allows multiple users to simultaneously edit and update the same document in real-time, facilitating team collaboration.
Documentation that is properly organized, current, and accessible to meet regulatory inspection requirements and compliance standards.
International Organization for Standardization - a global body that develops and publishes international standards for various industries including quality management.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted remotely and accessed via the internet rather than installed locally.
A centralized digital repository that stores and organizes information, documentation, and resources to provide easy access to institutional knowledge and procedures.
